overview: This subject is a detailed examination of the major elements of English grammar using principles of linguistic analysis. Students learn to identify and describe the main morphological and syntactic constructions in English including parts of speech, basic sentence structure, tense, aspect, clause type, negation, complex sentences, thematic systems, ellipsis, coordination, and the relations between sentences in discourse.
ilo: Attain in-depth knowledge of the major elements of English grammar
Apply skills in linguistic analysis utilising a variety of text types, and developed awareness of intellectual integrity
Make wide use of learning and research technologies (LMS, Library)
Further hone writing abilities across a variety of text types
Participate in individual and group-based problem-solving activities
generic_skills: Have developed their skills in critical thinking and analysis through tutorial discussion and completion of analytical exercises
Have developed their skills in thinking creatively and in theoretical terms through forming judgements and arguments from data and by critical analysis

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: Problem sets (2) due mid-semester and end of semester

assessment.hurdle: 1. Attendance hurdle requirement: This subject has a minimum requirement of 80% attendance at tutorials, seminars, or workshops. There is an expectation that students attend lectures.

2. Late Penalty and Assessment hurdle requirement: Assessment submitted late without an approved extension will be penalised at five per cent (5%) of the possible marks available for the assessment task per day or part thereof. All pieces of assessment must be submitted to pass the subject. Each submitted assessment must be complete, constitute a genuine attempt to address the requirements of the task and will not be accepted after 10 University business days from the original assessment due date without written approval.

date_times.contact_hours: 34 hours: 2 x 1 hour lecture and 1 x 1 hour tutorial per week. There will be no tutorials in the first and last weeks of semester.
